parts.question_text: Calculate the discriminant of \(f(x)\).  Explain how the sign of the discriminant relates to the number of real roots of the equation \(f(x) = 0\).
parts.solution_text: The discriminant, Δ, is given by Δ = \(b^2 - 4ac\), where \(a = -2\), \(b = 4\), and \(c = -5\).  Therefore, Δ = \(4^2 - 4(-2)(-5) = 16 - 40 = -24\). Since the discriminant is negative (Δ < 0), the equation \(f(x) = 0\) has no real roots.
